milestones.description: Complete Bachelor's degree in Telecommunications Engineering from SUP'COM
Intern as a Data Scientist at an organization in Sfax, Tunisia
Work as an AI Engineer at InstaDeep Ltd in Tunisia
Develop proficiency in Python programming
Gain experience in Deep Learning
Acquire skills in Data Science during internship
Master pandas and numpy libraries
Complete online course on Neural Networks and Deep Learning

causal_relationships.conditions: Must have completed at least 3 years of the Bachelor's program to qualify for most internship programs in Tunisia
causal_relationships.mechanism: The engineering degree provides the academic credential that internship programs require before allowing students to work on real data-science problems
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai and similar Nordic AI companies expect candidates to have a solid quantitative/engineering foundation; the SUP'COM degree is the entry ticket that unlocks internship eligibility and signals technical rigor to future employers.

causal_relationships.conditions: Graduation certificate must be awarded before full-time employment contract can be signed
causal_relationships.mechanism: InstaDeep’s standard offer process requires an attested degree for work-permit and HR compliance
causal_relationships.reasoning: Without the Bachelor’s credential, the candidate cannot legally hold an AI Engineer title in Tunisia, blocking the path toward the seniority boost.ai expects.

causal_relationships.conditions: Learner must have basic Python syntax and environment familiarity
causal_relationships.mechanism: Python proficiency allows the learner to import, manipulate, and benchmark pandas/numpy operations, turning abstract knowledge into usable skill
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai’s codebase is Python-centric; mastery of pandas/numpy is impossible without prior comfort in Python itself.

causal_relationships.conditions: None beyond basic Python fluency
causal_relationships.mechanism: Deep-learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch) are Python-based; solid Python skills lower the barrier to experimenting with neural networks
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai uses PyTorch for NLP models; a candidate who already codes fluently in Python can ramp up on Deep Learning faster.

causal_relationships.conditions: Internship project must involve tabular or text data processing
causal_relationships.mechanism: pandas/numpy skills accelerate data-cleaning and feature-engineering tasks assigned during the internship
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai values candidates who can demonstrate end-to-end data handling; internship output quality is higher when these libraries are mastered.

causal_relationships.conditions: Course must include hands-on labs or projects
causal_relationships.mechanism: Structured coursework provides theoretical background plus coding assignments that translate directly into Deep Learning experience
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai’s interview loop tests practical DL knowledge; completing a reputable online course supplies both concepts and portfolio artifacts.

causal_relationships.conditions: Internship must be completed before graduation or within 6 months after
causal_relationships.mechanism: Recruiters treat internship experience as a junior signal that justifies offering an Engineer title rather than another internship
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai prefers candidates with prior industry exposure; the internship serves as a stepping-stone that shortens the ramp-up time compared to hiring a fresh graduate.

causal_relationships.conditions: Deep Learning experience must be demonstrable via projects or Kaggle rankings
causal_relationships.mechanism: InstaDeep’s AI Engineer role involves implementing and tuning DL models; prior experience raises the candidate’s profile
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai’s conversational AI stack relies on transformer-based models; proven DL competence gained at InstaDeep is persuasive evidence.

causal_relationships.conditions: Skills acquired during internship must be aligned with production-grade ML engineering
causal_relationships.mechanism: Internship experience feeds into stronger performance as an AI Engineer, which in turn deepens practical Data-Science skills
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai values iterative growth; the synergy between internship-acquired DS skills and InstaDeep engineering experience creates a compelling narrative.

causal_relationships.conditions: Only if the AI Engineer role did not already cover advanced DL topics
causal_relationships.mechanism: If InstaDeep’s projects were focused on classical ML, the candidate may still need targeted Deep Learning upskilling via an online course
causal_relationships.reasoning: boost.ai may probe deeper into seq2seq or attention mechanisms; a supplemental course fills any remaining gaps.

goal_metadata.title: Quantitative Researcher at Qube Research & Technologies

milestones.description: Serve as a Data Scientist at boost.ai
Hold the position of Machine Learning Engineer at boost.ai
Achieve Competitions Master status on Kaggle
Earn gold and silver medals in Kaggle competitions
Attain 1st place in RSNA-MICCAI Brain Tumor Radiogenomic Classification competition on Kaggle
Complete Generative AI with Large Language Models certification
Develop expertise in developing quantitative models and strategies
Gain experience in applying machine learning in real-world scenarios

causal_relationships.conditions: Need at least one gold and multiple silver medals to reach Master tier
causal_relationships.mechanism: Kaggle awards points per medal; Master status requires cumulative points that can only be reached after earning gold/silver medals
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT values demonstrated excellence in competitive data science; Master status is impossible without prior medals, making this a strict prerequisite.

causal_relationships.conditions: Master-level feature engineering and modeling skills
causal_relationships.mechanism: Master tier grants access to higher-level competitions and collaborations that increase odds of a 1st-place finish
causal_relationships.reasoning: A 1st-place finish in a high-profile medical-imaging competition is a strong signal for QRT’s quant-research roles; Master status both qualifies and socially enables participation in elite teams.

causal_relationships.conditions: Typical internal promotion path at boost.ai
causal_relationships.mechanism: Engineers who prove they can ship ML systems are often promoted to DS roles that focus on experimentation and strategy
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT looks for evidence of increasing responsibility; moving from MLE → DS at the same firm shows a quantitatively driven growth trajectory.

causal_relationships.conditions: Access to production trading-adjacent data (chatbot intent prediction → demand forecasting)
causal_relationships.mechanism: As a Data Scientist at boost.ai, one designs A/B tests and predictive models that translate directly to quantitative-strategy development
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT’s researchers build statistical models for alpha; prior experience designing and validating such models in industry is direct preparation.

causal_relationships.conditions: End-to-end ownership of ML pipelines
causal_relationships.mechanism: Engineers deploy models to thousands of conversations, gaining real-world robustness experience
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT needs researchers who understand model failure modes in live environments; MLE experience provides this.

causal_relationships.conditions: Exposure to noisy, non-stationary data
causal_relationships.mechanism: Real-world ML teaches regularization and regime-shift detection—skills essential for quant models
causal_relationships.reasoning: While not strictly required, prior real-world ML experience makes the transition to quantitative-strategy design smoother and more credible.

causal_relationships.conditions: Focus on generative modeling for synthetic data generation
causal_relationships.mechanism: LLM-based generative techniques can augment limited financial datasets, a key technique in modern quant research
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT is exploring generative models for feature expansion; certification provides theoretical and practical grounding.

causal_relationships.conditions: Top-1 finish demonstrates ability to extract signal from high-dimensional medical imaging data
causal_relationships.mechanism: Transferable skill: extracting weak signals generalizes to extracting alpha from market data
causal_relationships.reasoning: QRT values competition victories as proof of research creativity and rigorous validation—both crucial for quantitative strategy development.

causal_relationships.conditions: Master tier indicates consistent high-level performance
causal_relationships.mechanism: Reputation and network effects open doors to quant research collaborations
causal_relationships.reasoning: Recruiters at QRT monitor Kaggle Masters; achieving this status increases visibility and perceived competence.

causal_relationships.conditions: Company sponsorship or time allocation for upskilling
causal_relationships.mechanism: Data Scientists at boost.ai are encouraged to pursue cutting-edge certifications
causal_relationships.reasoning: While not mandatory, holding a DS role makes it logistically and financially easier to complete advanced certifications.

causal_relationships.conditions: Evening/weekend availability for competitions
causal_relationships.mechanism: MLE role builds core modeling skills that accelerate competition performance
causal_relationships.reasoning: Strong engineering skills reduce iteration time in competitions, indirectly boosting medal count.

causal_relationships.conditions: Exposure to business KPIs sharpens feature engineering intuition
causal_relationships.mechanism: DS role teaches how to translate business problems into modeling tasks—useful for competition framing
causal_relationships.reasoning: Although not required, DS experience can improve competition performance by aligning solutions with implicit objectives.

causal_relationships.conditions: Medals accumulate points toward Master tier
causal_relationships.mechanism: A 1st-place gold medal yields large point gains, while prior medals lower the barrier to entering and winning future competitions
causal_relationships.reasoning: Success in one high-stakes competition boosts confidence and skill, leading to more medals and faster Master progression.

goal_metadata.title: Machine Learning Researcher at a Stealth Startup

milestones.description: Serve as a Quantitative Researcher at Qube Research & Technologies
Hold the position of Chief Technology Officer at BabaConda Technologies
Participate in Kaggle competitions and maintain high rankings
Implement cutting-edge BERT model for Google QUEST QA Labeling competition
Acquire expertise in data science and machine learning
Develop proficiency in French, Arabic, and English languages
Complete projects demonstrating advanced AI research skills
Enhance skills in developing robust machine learning models

causal_relationships.conditions: Requires formal education or self-taught mastery of DS/ML fundamentals
causal_relationships.mechanism: Core DS/ML knowledge is a hiring gate for quantitative research roles
causal_relationships.reasoning: Qube Research & Technologies hires Quantitative Researchers only after verifying deep DS/ML expertise; without m5, candidate would not pass technical interviews.

causal_relationships.conditions: Basic Python, statistics, and ML libraries must be mastered
causal_relationships.mechanism: Foundational skills allow meaningful participation in Kaggle competitions
causal_relationships.reasoning: Kaggle competitions assume familiarity with scikit-learn, pandas, PyTorch/TensorFlow; m5 provides these prerequisites.

causal_relationships.conditions: Need prior competition experience to tackle advanced NLP tasks
causal_relationships.mechanism: High Kaggle ranking signals readiness for cutting-edge model implementation
causal_relationships.reasoning: Google QUEST QA competition is expert-level; prior Kaggle success (m3) is de-facto required to attempt m4.

causal_relationships.conditions: Successful competition submission and public write-up
causal_relationships.mechanism: Competition project becomes flagship research demonstration
causal_relationships.reasoning: A top-percentile BERT solution in m4 can be framed as an advanced AI research project, directly satisfying m7.

causal_relationships.conditions: Project must involve iterative model robustness improvements
causal_relationships.mechanism: Research projects expose edge cases that drive robustness skill growth
causal_relationships.reasoning: Executing m7 forces hands-on handling of noisy data, adversarial examples, and cross-validation, thereby enhancing robust-ML skills (m8).

causal_relationships.conditions: Requires 3-5 years of quant research experience
causal_relationships.mechanism: Industry progression from senior researcher to CTO
causal_relationships.reasoning: Moving from Quant Researcher (m1) to CTO (m2) is a natural seniority jump after demonstrating leadership and business acumen.

causal_relationships.conditions: Startup operates in MENA/European markets
causal_relationships.mechanism: CTO role in bilingual startup necessitates language skills
causal_relationships.reasoning: If BabaConda Technologies (m2) serves Arabic- and French-speaking markets, language proficiency (m6) becomes strategically valuable.

causal_relationships.conditions: Continuous learning and experimentation
causal_relationships.mechanism: Foundational knowledge enables iterative robustness improvements
causal_relationships.reasoning: Deep DS/ML expertise (m5) is necessary to understand regularization, data augmentation, and uncertainty quantification required for robust models (m8).

causal_relationships.conditions: Focus on competitions with noisy or adversarial datasets
causal_relationships.mechanism: Kaggle experience exposes robustness challenges
causal_relationships.reasoning: Competitions often contain label noise and distribution shift; tackling them (m3) directly trains robust-ML intuition (m8).

causal_relationships.conditions: Employer allows publication or open-source release
causal_relationships.mechanism: Quant research role provides compute resources and datasets
causal_relationships.reasoning: Working at Qube (m1) gives access to large-scale financial data and GPU clusters, enabling high-impact AI research projects (m7).

causal_relationships.conditions: Stealth startup targets global or multilingual markets
causal_relationships.mechanism: Multilingual ability aids cross-cultural team collaboration
causal_relationships.reasoning: Stealth startups often hire small, versatile teams; language skills (m6) make candidate more attractive for international expansion.

causal_relationships.conditions: CTO experience in AI-driven startup
causal_relationships.mechanism: Executive experience signals ability to drive research agenda
causal_relationships.reasoning: Having led BabaConda (m2) demonstrates capability to set technical vision, a key trait for a senior ML Researcher in a stealth startup.

causal_relationships.conditions: Projects must be high-impact and peer-recognized
causal_relationships.mechanism: Research portfolio convinces stealth startup of candidate’s value
causal_relationships.reasoning: Stealth startups hire researchers who can ship novel models; strong project demonstrations (m7) directly satisfy this requirement.

causal_relationships.conditions: Demonstrated robustness in production settings
causal_relationships.mechanism: Robust-ML skills reduce product risk for stealth startup
causal_relationships.reasoning: Stealth startups cannot afford model failures; proven robustness expertise (m8) makes candidate indispensable.

goal_metadata.title: Research Assistant at University of Louisville

milestones.description: Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science from Tunisia Polytechnic School
Engage in theoretical modeling of feedback loops in recommender systems
Research work accepted at Recsys 2020
Explore interpretability for deep learning architectures
Counter exposure bias in matrix factorization
Design an explainable active learning strategy for recommender systems

causal_relationships.conditions: Must have completed core undergraduate courses in algorithms, probability, and linear algebra
causal_relationships.mechanism: The Bachelor's degree provides the mathematical maturity and programming background required to understand and implement feedback-loop models in recommender systems
causal_relationships.reasoning: A Research Assistant position at a U.S. university typically requires an accredited Bachelor's degree as a minimum qualification; without this credential, visa sponsorship and admission to graduate programs (common routes to RA roles) are impossible

causal_relationships.conditions: Must have institutional affiliation or prior publication history to submit to RecSys
causal_relationships.mechanism: The degree grants student status, which allows conference registration and advisor sponsorship necessary for paper submission
causal_relationships.reasoning: Most top-tier CS conferences require an academic email or institutional endorsement; a Bachelor's from Tunisia Polytechnic School satisfies this requirement

causal_relationships.conditions: Research must be novel and rigorously evaluated
causal_relationships.mechanism: The theoretical modeling work in m2 generates the core contribution that is then written up and peer-reviewed for RecSys 2020
causal_relationships.reasoning: A RecSys publication needs a concrete technical contribution; m2 supplies the modeling framework and results that become the paper

causal_relationships.conditions: Visibility from RecSys publication attracts collaborators interested in interpretability
causal_relationships.mechanism: Having a RecSys paper establishes credibility, making professors at University of Louisville more willing to supervise follow-up work on interpretability
causal_relationships.reasoning: A prior publication demonstrates research competence, a key filter used by U.S. faculty when selecting RAs

causal_relationships.conditions: RecSys networking leads to exposure-bias collaboration
causal_relationships.mechanism: Conference exposure introduces the candidate to faculty working on bias issues, facilitating joint projects
causal_relationships.reasoning: Many bias-in-RS papers emerge from post-conference collaborations; m3 provides the venue

causal_relationships.conditions: RecSys publication is leveraged in RA application to demonstrate domain expertise
causal_relationships.mechanism: The publication serves as writing sample and proof of research ability in the RA interview process
causal_relationships.reasoning: University of Louisville labs hiring RAs often ask for a writing sample; m3 fulfills this requirement

causal_relationships.conditions: Feedback-loop insights inform bias analysis
causal_relationships.mechanism: Understanding feedback loops helps identify how exposure bias propagates in matrix factorization models
causal_relationships.reasoning: Both milestones deal with systemic biases in recommender systems; insights from m2 provide theoretical grounding for m5

causal_relationships.conditions: Interpretability techniques must be integrated into active learning strategy
causal_relationships.mechanism: The interpretability research in m4 yields methods that are incorporated into the explainable active learning framework of m6
causal_relationships.reasoning: An explainable active learning strategy requires interpretable models; m4 supplies these components

causal_relationships.conditions: Bias mitigation techniques improve active learning sample selection
causal_relationships.mechanism: Countering exposure bias leads to more representative training data, which enhances the active learning strategy
causal_relationships.reasoning: Active learning queries can be skewed by exposure bias; m5 techniques reduce this skew

causal_relationships.conditions: Deep learning coursework completed during Bachelor's
causal_relationships.mechanism: Undergraduate deep learning courses provide the foundation needed to explore interpretability in advanced architectures
causal_relationships.reasoning: Without foundational DL knowledge from the Bachelor's program, tackling interpretability research would be premature

causal_relationships.conditions: Linear algebra and optimization background from Bachelor's
causal_relationships.mechanism: Matrix factorization techniques require linear algebra and optimization theory covered in the undergraduate curriculum
causal_relationships.reasoning: Exposure bias mitigation in MF models relies on mathematical tools learned during the Bachelor's degree

causal_relationships.conditions: Coursework in human-computer interaction and machine learning
causal_relationships.mechanism: The Bachelor's curriculum includes courses that introduce active learning and HCI principles necessary for m6
causal_relationships.reasoning: Designing an explainable strategy requires both ML and HCI knowledge typically acquired at the undergraduate level

milestones.description: Complete Master of Science in Computer Science from University of Louisville
Collaborate with the AI-Recommendations team

causal_relationships.conditions: Must be enrolled in or have completed at least the first year of the MS program with coursework in machine learning and data mining
causal_relationships.mechanism: The MS curriculum provides the theoretical grounding (deep learning, optimization, NLP) and the student status that makes a university–industry collaboration project with Bloomberg’s AI-Recommendations team possible
causal_relationships.reasoning: Bloomberg’s Research Intern postings typically require applicants to be currently enrolled in a graduate CS/EE program. Completing the MS at University of Louisville not only satisfies this enrollment requirement but also equips the candidate with the advanced coursework and faculty connections that are prerequisites for being invited to collaborate on the AI-Recommendations team.

causal_relationships.conditions: GPA ≥ 3.7 and completion of at least two graduate-level ML courses
causal_relationships.mechanism: The MS program provides access to faculty research groups that have existing partnerships with Bloomberg; high-performing students are nominated for these industry projects
causal_relationships.reasoning: Without the formal structure of the MS program, an external candidate would lack the institutional endorsement and research background that Bloomberg uses to shortlist interns. The degree therefore enables but does not strictly require the collaboration.

causal_relationships.conditions: None beyond normal progression
causal_relationships.mechanism: Course projects in the MS can be aligned with recommender-system topics, producing portfolio artifacts that strengthen the collaboration application
causal_relationships.reasoning: Even if the collaboration could theoretically occur without the MS, the degree supplies coursework and project experience that materially improve the quality of the candidate’s contribution to the AI-Recommendations team.

causal_relationships.conditions: Collaboration must yield a co-authored publication or thesis chapter
causal_relationships.mechanism: Success in the Bloomberg collaboration feeds back into the MS thesis, improving the final degree outcome and vice versa
causal_relationships.reasoning: A productive collaboration can generate research results that count toward the MS thesis requirements, while the thesis work can deepen the insights contributed to the Bloomberg team, creating a virtuous cycle.

milestones.description: PhD in Computer Science from University of Louisville
Focus on building scalable recommender systems
Enhance AI systems for internal coding tools
Work on large language models (LLMs)
Serve as Tech Lead for Facebook Video Recommendations
Concentrate on large-scale ranking and late-stage personalization models

causal_relationships.conditions: PhD must be completed or near-completion before deep specialization in recommender systems is credible at Meta-level scale
causal_relationships.mechanism: PhD provides theoretical grounding in ML, optimization, and systems thinking required to design novel recommender architectures
causal_relationships.reasoning: Meta’s Staff Research Scientist job family typically requires a PhD for research credibility; without it, the candidate would be filtered out before technical depth in recommender systems is even evaluated.

causal_relationships.conditions: PhD dissertation must demonstrate publication record in NLP or large-model training
causal_relationships.mechanism: PhD research yields first-author papers at ACL/NeurIPS/ICML, which are prerequisites for Meta research interviews
causal_relationships.reasoning: Staff-level hiring committees look for PhD-level evidence of advancing LLM science; terminal-degree research is the standard gate.

causal_relationships.conditions: At least 3-4 years post-PhD building production-scale recommenders
causal_relationships.mechanism: Deep expertise in recommender systems is the exact skill set needed to lead Facebook Video Recommendations
causal_relationships.reasoning: Video recommendations at Meta’s scale require cutting-edge retrieval and ranking; prior specialization in recommenders is non-negotiable for Tech Lead credibility.

causal_relationships.conditions: Experience fine-tuning LLMs for code generation tasks
causal_relationships.mechanism: LLM expertise allows transfer to code-model domain; internal tools leverage similar transformer architectures
causal_relationships.reasoning: Meta’s internal coding assistants (e.g., CodeCompose) build directly on LLM advances; prior LLM work lowers ramp-up time.

causal_relationships.conditions: Successful delivery of video ranking improvements with measurable impact
causal_relationships.mechanism: Tech Lead role provides mandate to push ranking and personalization boundaries at Meta scale
causal_relationships.reasoning: Staff promotion cases hinge on demonstrated impact; leading video recommendations gives platform to innovate on late-stage ranking.

causal_relationships.conditions: Continued publication record in recommender systems
causal_relationships.mechanism: Foundational recommender knowledge informs advanced ranking and personalization research
causal_relationships.reasoning: Even after moving to Tech Lead, ongoing recommender research keeps candidate’s profile aligned with Meta’s product needs.

causal_relationships.conditions: Cross-pollination between code-model efficiency and ranking-model efficiency
causal_relationships.mechanism: Optimizations for LLM inference translate to ranking-model serving; vice-versa for personalization
causal_relationships.reasoning: Meta values researchers who connect disparate domains; innovations in internal tools can inspire ranking breakthroughs.

causal_relationships.conditions: PhD completion precedes Tech Lead role by ~4-6 years of industry experience
causal_relationships.mechanism: Career ladder at Meta requires PhD + years of post-doc or industry research before Staff-level leadership
causal_relationships.reasoning: Meta’s internal leveling guidelines place PhD as baseline; Tech Lead for core product is rarely given to pre-PhD candidates.

causal_relationships.conditions: LLM knowledge applied to multimodal video understanding
causal_relationships.mechanism: Modern video recommenders use LLMs for metadata and content understanding
causal_relationships.reasoning: While not strictly required, LLM expertise strengthens the case for leading next-gen video recommendations.
